id_table_1.caption: Comparisons with state-of-the-art approaches on three knowledge-based reasoning datasets based on GPT-3.5-turbo and Claude. Here, our implementation only includes twoand one.
table: Method GPT-3.5-turbo Claude ScienceQA Com2sense BoolQ ScienceQA Com2sense BoolQ zero-shot setting Base 79.3 70.1 71.7 86.8 75.3 73.4 CoT (Kojima et al. 2022 ) 78.4 63.6 71.1 86.5 74.7 70.9 SC-CoT (Wang et al. 2023b ) 84.0 66.0 71.4 86.5 77.4 71.1 C-CoT (Fu et al. 2022 ) 82.5 68.8 70.5 86.6 76.5 70.2 CaCo-CoT (ours) 86.5 73.5 73.5 89.9 78.0 76.7 one-shot setting CoT (Wei et al. 2022b ) 82.6 70.6 70.2 89.5 78.8 72.3 SC-CoT (Wang et al. 2023b ) 86.3 72.4 70.3 90.0 80.6 70.9 C-CoT (Fu et al. 2022 ) 86.9 71.9 68.9 90.1 79.7 70.7 L2M-CoT (Zhou et al. 2023 ) 84.1 64.5 68.9 90.2 70.0 76.2 CaCo-CoT (ours) 88.6 75.0 75.0 90.8 83.0 77.9
references: To more concisely refer to methods, we shorten Chain-of-thought to CoT, Self-Consistent CoT           (Wang et al.             2023b            )          to SC-CoT, Complexity-based CoT           (Fu et al.             2022            )          to C-CoT and Least-to-Most to L2M-CoT.                Science Question Answering          embodies the procedure of memorizing and employing scientific knowledge to comprehend, explain, and predict phenomena in the natural world. In Table                  1                , we compare our method with several methods to elicit reasoning in LLMs, including CoT, SC-CoT, C-CoT, and L2M-CoT prompting in both zero-shot and one-shot settings. Here, the L2M-CoT prompting can be only implemented in a one-shot manner as it has to demonstrate how to decompose a problem and address subquestions one by one. Note that our approach’s implementation in Table                  1                only includes two           reasoner          agents and one           evaluator          agent.          As shown in the first and fourth columns of Table                  1                , our method outperforms the existing methods in both settings using two different LLMs, GPT-3.5-turbo           (Ouyang et al.             2022            )          (by margins of 2.5% for the zero-shot and 1.7% for the one-shot setting, separately) and Claude           (Bai et al.             2022            )          (3.5% and 0.6%), while being more efficient with lower invocation times. We also find that our zero-shot performance matches that of SC-CoT and C-CoT with one-shot learning. This improvement can be attributed to that our CaCo-CoT approach boosts factualness accuracy in scientific knowledge and reduces inference fallacies.

Commonsense reasoning aims to answer questions that require reasoning over general background knowledge. Commonsense reasoning capability is essential for AI deployed in the real world. Strong commonsense reasoning capabilities restrict AI from functioning within reasonable and safe boundaries. Specifically, we employ the same experiment setting as Science Question Answering.            As shown in Table                     1                   , our method outperforms the existing methods in both Com2Sense and BoolQ.As we observed, CoT-based approaches             (Wei et al.               2022b              ; Wang et al.               2023b              )            usually fall short of correctly employing relevant background knowledge implied by the question, because they often embark on knowledge inference before having a clear definition of the knowledge in the context of the given question.Step-by-step reasoning may proceed in a ”plan-as-you-go” manner (i.e., without a clear plan to arrive at the answer), which may be misleading when facing multi-hop reasoning problems.Our approach prompts the             reasoner            agents to explicitly extract the knowledge and decompose the question into a group of subquestions before reasoning, which is a low-risk and effective way to perform knowledge inference.Moreover, the solution will be inspected by our             evaluator            agent to ensure causal consistency, including non-causal inspection and counterfactual reasoning for another potential answer.Notably, our approach showcases its powerful reasoning capability. There is more than 3% accuracy improvement for the zero-shot setting and 2.6% for the one-shot setting on Com2sense in GPT-3.5-turbo. Additionally, around 3.5% accuracy improvement on BoolQ and 2.4% on Com2sense in Claude can be witnessed, only through learning to follow the reasoning and evaluating procedure. Overall, our CaCo-CoT approach mostly outperforms the state-of-the-art counterparts on the Com2sense and BoolQ datasets.

The level of grade represents the difficulty of the question.  †  denotes zero-shot setting and  ‡  denotes one-shot setting.

references: Table                     2                   presents a comparison of the results obtained from various implementations of the proposed method, CaCo-CoT, alongside some compared methods. These implementations are evaluated across diverse disciplines and levels on the ScienceQA dataset.For SC-CoT and C-CoT, we sample 10 reasoning chains for majority voting, following the original papers.For our variance of voting among three             reasoners            , if two or more than two             reasoners            arrive at a single answer, we accept the answer as the final output.

id_table_3.caption: Ablation Study of CaCO-CoTon the Com2sense datasetwhere GPT-3.5 is short for GPT-3.5-turbo. Without any component, theis far from its best performance.
table: Model Agent Type Ablated Component Acc. GPT-3.5 Reasoner Concept explanation 69.6 Evaluator Non-causal Evaluation 70.2 Evaluator Counterfactual Evaluation 72.0 Evaluator Reconsideration 71.1 N/A N/A 73.5 Claude Reasoner concept explanation 74.1 Evaluator Non-causal Evaluation 76.2 Evaluator Counterfactual Evaluation 76.9 N/A N/A 77.9
references: To study the individual components proposed in this paper, we conduct a range of ablative experiments on Com2sense dataset. As shown in Table                     3                   , we first ablate the             concept explanation            component of the             reasoner            . After that, the individual component of             non-causal evaluation            ,             counterfactual evaluation            for the             evaluator            is respectively ablated. The resulting accuracy reveals that the causal-consistency-seeking process is crucial for the commonsense reasoning task. When the             concept explanation            component is employed, performance balloons, with gains of up to 3.9% on GPT-3.5-turbo and 3.8% on Claude. The             non-causal evaluation            component that examines the solution after a full scan of it increases the final accuracy by 3.3% on GPT-3.5-turbo and 1.7% on Claude. Moreover, When inspecting solutions through a reversed reasoning process, termed as             counterfactual evaluation            , both GPT-3.5-turbo and Claude exhibit an increase in accuracy by 1.5% and 1.0% separately.

id_table_4.caption: CaCo-CoT versus CoT on the zero-shot setting. The green highlight indicates the positive content that contributes to the correct answer, while the red portions represent unfaithful or misleading content.
table: Question: Which word is not like the others? Options: (A) clown. (B) room. (C) king. (D) teacher. Right Answer: B . CaCo-CoT Reasoner 1 : Answer: E . 1.Explanation of Terms : ”Not like the others” means that one of the options is different or does not belong in the same category as the others . 2.Subquestion Decomposition and Answering : subquestion1: What is the common characteristic or category of the options? Answer: The options are all nouns, but do not have a common characteristic . subquesiton2: Which option does not belong or is different from the others? Answer: It is difficult to determine which option is different from the others. 3.Reasoning: It is not possible to determine which option is not like the others . CaCo-CoT Evaluator 1 : Answer: B . 1.Evaluation: The explanation of ”Not like the others” is clear. The answer to subquestion 2 is incorrect . The solution incorrectly concludes that it is difficult to determine which option is not like the others, but this is not true. It is possible to determine which option is different based on a common characteristic or category. The answer is incorrect. 2.Counterfactual reasoning : If we consider ”room” as the answer, it does not fit the common characteristic or category of the other options. The other options are all occupations or roles (clown, king, teacher), while ”room” is a physical space or location. There is no contradiction in this case. In fact, it corrects the initial mistake incorrectly states that it is difficult to determine which option is not like the others. 3.Re-reasoning: First, identify a common characteristic among the options. Upon examination, ”clown,” ”king,” and ”teacher” are all occupations or roles. However, ”room” does not fit this common characteristic or category. It is a physical space or location, not an occupation or role. Therefore, the most likely answer is (B) room. CoT Sample 1 : Answer : C 1. … 2. ’Clown’, ’room’ and ’teacher’ are common nouns referring to occupations, places or people. 3. ’King’ refers to a royal title , which is different. 4. The answer is ’king’. CoT Sample 2 : Answer : C 1. … 2. … 3. Options A, B and D are all nouns that refer to people or places. Option C, ’king’, refers to a person as well. 4. The word that is not like the others is ’king’ . CoT Sample 3 : Answer : D 1. … 2. ’Clown’, ’room’, and ’king’ are all nouns. 3. ’Teacher’ is the only verb in the options . 4.’teacher’ is not like the other nouns. CoT Sample 4 : Answer : B 1. … 2. … 3. ’Clown’, ’king’, and ’teacher’ are all occupations or roles. 4. ’Room’ refers to a place or space and does not share the attribute of being an occupation with the others.
references: In this subsection, we conduct a case study to understand how our approach works in detail, shown in Table                  4                . To reduce the uncertainty of sampling results, we obtained responses to the query from GPT-3.5-turbo ten times and compiled a list of the main responses. We find that it occasionally provides the correct answer, albeit with a low probability, demonstrated in Sample           4          . More frequently, it makes typical mistakes such as lacking timeliness in understanding concepts, shown in Sample           1          ; inconsistent context, shown in Sample           2          and misunderstanding of knowledge, shown in Sample           3          . These phenomena indicate that if users aim to obtain the correct answer, they should repeatedly inquire with LLM, which is highly inefficient. In our method, based on the knowledge acquired from the step of           concept explanation          , the           reasoner          is confused during the problem decomposition process and thus cannot provide a discriminative answer. However, the           evaluator          can 1) identify the mistakes made by the           reasoner          , i.e., confusion in the subquestion decomposition step; 2) Through counterfactual reasoning, it incorporates factual knowledge to support the counterfactual answer and find no contradiction when applying it, i.e., ”The other options are all occupations or roles (clown, king, teacher), while ’room’ is a physical space or location”. 3) Finally, it corrects the final choice to the golden one, (B) room.

id_table_5.caption: A single-round case of CaCo-CoTversus CoTon BoolQ,denotes the one-shot settings.The green highlight indicates the positive content that contributes to the correct answer, while the blue portions represent unfaithful or misleading content.
table: Question : were the twin towers taller than empire state building? Right Answer : yes CaCo-CoT ‡ : Reasoner 1 : 1. Explanation of Concepts : The Twin Towers, also known as the World Trade Center, were two skyscrapers in Lower Manhattan, New York City. The North Tower and South Tower were completed in 1973 and stood at 110 stories and 1,362 feet high . The Empire State Building is a 102-story skyscraper located in Midtown Manhattan, New York City. It has a roof height of 1,250 feet and stands a total of 1,454 feet high . 2. Subquestion Decomposition and Answering : subquestion 1: Were the Twin Towers taller than the Empire State Building in terms of height? Answer: Yes, the Twin Towers stood at 1,362 feet high, which is taller than the Empire State Building at 1,250 feet . 3. Rationale for the Answer : Based on the information provided, the Twin Towers at 1,362 feet high were taller than the Empire State Building at 1,250 feet high . Therefore, the answer is yes. Answer : yes Reasoner 2 : 1. Explanation of Concepts : The Twin Towers, also known as the World Trade Center, were two skyscrapers in Lower Manhattan, New York City. The original World Trade Center complex was destroyed in the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001. The Empire State Building is a 102-story Art Deco skyscraper in Midtown Manhattan, New York City. It was the world’s tallest building for nearly 40 years, from its completion in 1931 until the construction of the World Trade Center’s North Tower in 1972. 2. Subquestion Decomposition and Answering : subquestion 1: How tall were the Twin Towers? Answer: The Twin Towers were 1,368 feet (417 m) tall . subquestion 2: How tall is the Empire State Building? Answer: The Empire State Building is 1,250 feet (381 m) tall . 3. Rationale for the Answer : By comparing the heights of the Twin Towers and Empire State Building, it is clear that the Twin Towers were taller. Answer : yes Evaluator, Evaluation 1 : 1. Evaluation : The explanation provides the necessary and factual background information on the Twin Towers and Empire State Building, including their heights. The subquestion on whether the Twin Towers were taller than the Empire State Building in terms of height is answered correctly based on the height information provided. The reasoning process is logical. There are no obvious flaws in the reasoning. The answer ”yes” is supported by the reasoning and evidence . 2. Counterfactual Reasoning : The answer could potentially be ”no” if the heights of the buildings were compared incorrectly or if additional information on the buildings’ heights comes to light. If the answer were ”no”, it would contradict the evidence and reasoning provided based on the current information. 3. Re-reasoning : 1) The Twin Towers stood at 1,362 feet high. 2) The Empire State Building stood at 1,250 feet high. 3) 1,362 feet is greater than 1,250 feet . 4) Therefore, the Twin Towers were taller than the Empire State Building. Answer : yes CoT ‡ : Sample 1 : To determine if the Twin Towers were taller than the Empire State Building, we need to compare their heights. 1) Find the height of the Twin Towers. The North Tower of the World Trade Center (Twin Towers) had a height of 1,368 feet (417 meters) , and the South Tower had a height of 1,362 feet (415 meters) . 2) Find the height of the Empire State Building. The Empire State Building has a height of 1,454 feet (443.2 meters) . 3) Compare the heights. Comparing the heights, we can see that the Empire State Building is taller than both the North and South Towers of the World Trade Center. Therefore, the answer is: no, the Twin Towers were not taller than the Empire State Building . Answer : no
references: In Table                  5                , we showcase how our approach significantly elicits more faithful knowledge reasoning in LLMs by lowering factual errors. In this case, our           reasoner          agents provide accurate and factual background knowledge about the heights of the Twin Towers and the Empire State Building. By simply comparing them, our           reasoners          derive the correct answer ’yes’. Contrastively, one-shot CoT offers a hallucination, i.e., the heights of two buildings are both in factually inaccurate numbers. This leads to a mistake in the final answer. Note that the base model behind these two approaches is identical. We only prompt the           reasoners          to recall the background knowledge in the first place, which is straightforward and efficient.

id_table_6.caption: A single-round case of CaCo-CoTversus CoTfor a dictionary guide words question on ScienceQA, wheredenotes the zero-shot settings. The green highlight indicates the positive content that contributes to the correct answer, while the blue portions represent unfaithful or misleading content.
table: Question : Which word would you find on a dictionary page with the following guide words? garage - goose Options : (A) guess; (B) glow; Right Answer : B CaCo-CoT † : Answer : A Reasoner 1 : 1. Explanation of Concepts : ’Guide words’ are the words that appear at the top of each page in a dictionary . They help the reader find the word they are looking for by indicating the first and last words on the page . 2. Subquestion Decomposition and Answering : subquestion 1: What is the first word on the page? Answer: The first word on the page is ”garage” . subquestion 2: What is the last word on the page? Answer: The last word on the page is ”goose” . 3. Rationale for the Answer : The guide words ”garage” and ”goose” indicate that the words on the page fall between these two words in alphabetical order . Since ”guess” comes before ”goose” in alphabetical order, it would be the word found on the dictionary page . Answer : A Reasoner 2 : 1. Explanation of Concepts : ’Guide words’ are the words that appear at the top of each page in a dictionary . They indicate the first and last words on that page . 2. Subquestion Decomposition and Answering : subquestion 1: What is the first word on the page? Answer: The first word on the page is ”garage” . subquestion 2: What is the last word on the page? Answer: The last word on the page is ”goose” . 3. Rationale for the Answer : The guide words ”garage” and ”goose” indicate that the words on the page will be alphabetically between these two words. Since ”guess” comes after ”garage” and before ”goose” alphabetically, it would be the word found on the dictionary page . Answer : A Evaluator, Evaluation 1 : 1. Evaluation : The explanation of guide words is accurate. The subquestions are correctly identified and answered. The reasoning process is logical. The answer ”guess” is correctly determined based on the reasoning process . 2. Counterfactual Reasoning : Option (B): ”glow” needs to be considered as a possible word on the dictionary page. If ”glow” is the word on the dictionary page, it would contradict the alphabetical order between ”garage” and ”goose” . 3. Re-reasoning : 1) The guide words are ”garage” and ”goose”. 2) The word on the dictionary page should be alphabetically between ”garage” and ”goose”. 3) ”Guess” comes after ”garage” and before ”goose” alphabetically . 4) Option (B) ”glow” would contradict the alphabetical order. 5) Therefore, the most likely word on the dictionary page is ”guess”. Answer : A CoT † : Sample 1 : First, the guide words given are ”garage” and ”goose”. Next, we need to find a word that would be listed between these guide words . Looking at the options, the word ”guess” would come before ”garage” in alphabetical order , so it would not be listed between ”garage” and ”goose”. On the other hand, the word ”glow” would come after ”goose” in alphabetical order , so it would not be listed between ”garage” and ”goose” either. Therefore, the correct answer is none of the above. Answer : Neither Sample 2 : First, the guide words given are ”garage” and ”goose”. Next, we need to find a word that would come alphabetically between ”garage” and ”goose”. Looking at the options, ”guess” comes alphabetically after ”garage” but before ”goose” . Therefore, the word you would find on a dictionary page with the given guide words is ”guess”. Answer : A Sample 3 : The guide words ”garage” and ”goose” indicate that the word we are looking for falls alphabetically between these two words. When we compare the options ”guess” and ”glow” to the guide words, we can see that ”guess” comes before ”garage” alphabetically, while ”glow” comes after ”goose” . Therefore, the word that would be found on a dictionary page with the guide words ”garage” and ”goose” is (B) glow . Answer : B Sample 4 : First, we need to determine the alphabetical order of the guide words ”garage” and ”goose”. ”G” comes before ”G”, so ”garage” would come before ”goose” in alphabetical order. Next, we need to find a word that would come after ”garage” and before ”goose” in alphabetical order. The word ”glow” comes after ”garage” and before ”goose” in alphabetical order . Therefore, the word ”glow” would be the word you would find on a dictionary page with the guide words ”garage” and ”goose”. Answer : B

id_table_7.caption: The given question to determine the sentence with a vague pronoun on ScienceQAThe response of CaCo-CoT.The response of CoT(SC-CoT).A multi-round case study of CoTversus CoT. The green highlight indicates the positive content that contributes to the correct answer, while the blue portions represent unfaithful or misleading content.
table: Question: Which of the following contains a vague pronoun reference? Right Answer : A Options: (A) Emma took the memory card out of the digital camera and put it in her desk drawer. (B) Emma took the memory card out of the digital camera and put the card in her desk drawer.
references: Table                     7                   shows a scenario where both CaCo-CoT and CoT fail short of answering a question to find a sentence with a vague pronoun reference.

id_table_8.caption: The given question to determine the sentence with a vague pronoun on ScienceQA
table: Question: Which of the following contains a vague pronoun reference? Right Answer : A Options: (A) Emma took the memory card out of the digital camera and put it in her desk drawer. (B) Emma took the memory card out of the digital camera and put the card in her desk drawer.

id_table_9.caption: The response of CaCo-CoT.
table:
Round One : Reasoning Stage
\hdashline Reasoner 1 : 1. Explanation of Concepts : ’Vague pronoun reference’ refers to a situation where a pronoun is used, but it is unclear what noun the pronoun is referring to . … 3. Rationale for the Answer : In option (B), the pronoun ”it” is used without a clear antecedent. It is unclear what ”it” is referring to - the memory card or the digital camera . This creates a vague pronoun reference. Answer : B Reasoner 2 : 1. Explanation of Concepts : ’Vague pronoun reference’ refers to a situation where a pronoun is used, but it is unclear what noun the pronoun is referring to . … 3. Rationale for the Answer : In option (A), the pronoun ”it” is used, but it is unclear what noun ”it” is referring to. It could refer to the memory card or the digital camera. In option (B), the pronoun ”it” is replaced with the noun ”card,” making the reference clear . Answer : A Round One: Evaluation Stage \hdashline Evaluator , Evaluation 1 : 1. Evaluation : The explanation of vague pronoun reference is accurate and clear. The subquestion is clearly stated and answered correctly. The reasoning process is logical and follows a clear path. The answer is correct, as option B does contain a vague pronoun reference . 2. Counterfactual Reasoning : Option A needs to be considered as well. If we apply option A, there is no vague pronoun reference . There will not be a contradiction. 3. Re-reasoning : 1) Evaluate option A: ”Emma took the memory card out of the digital camera and put it in her desk drawer.” In this sentence, the pronoun ”it” clearly refers to the memory card, so there is no vague pronoun reference . 2) Evaluate option B: ”Emma took the memory card out of the digital camera and put the card in her desk drawer.” In this sentence, the pronoun ”it” is used without a clear antecedent. It is unclear what ”it” is referring to - the memory card or the digital camera . This creates a vague pronoun reference. Answer : B Evaluator , Evaluation 2 : 1. Evaluation : The explanation of the term ”vague pronoun reference” is accurate and clear. The subquestion is clear and the answer is correct. The reasoning process is logical and follows a clear path. The answer is correct, as an option (A) contains a vague pronoun reference . 2. Counterfactual Reasoning : The option to look out for is an option (B). If we apply option (B), the pronoun reference is no longer vague as the noun ”card” is used instead of the pronoun ”it” . 3. Re-reasoning : 1) Option (A) contains a vague pronoun reference with the pronoun ”it” . 2) Option (B) replaces the pronoun ”it” with the noun ”card”, making the reference clear . 3) Therefore, option (B) does not contain a vague pronoun reference. Answer : A Round Two: Reasoning Stage
\hdashline Reasoner 1 : 1. Explanation of Concepts : A vague pronoun reference occurs when it is unclear which noun the pronoun is referring to . 2. Subquestion Decomposition and Answering : subquestion 1: Is there a pronoun in the sentence? Answer: Yes, there is a pronoun in the sentence . subquestion 2: Is the pronoun in the sentence vague? Answer: No, the pronoun in the sentence is not vague . 3. Rationale for the Answer : In the given sentence, the pronoun ”it” clearly refers to the noun ”memory card.” There is no ambiguity or vagueness in the pronoun reference . Answer : B Reasoner 2 : 1. Explanation of Concepts : Vague pronoun reference refers to a situation where a pronoun is used, but it is unclear what noun the pronoun is referring to . This can lead to confusion or ambiguity in the sentence. … 3. Rationale for the Answer : In option (B), the pronoun ”it” is used without a clear antecedent. It is unclear what ”it” is referring to - the memory card or the digital camera. This creates a vague pronoun reference . Answer : B Round Two: Evaluation Stage
\hdashline Evaluator 1 : 1. Evaluation : …The reasoning process is logical and follows a clear path. …The answer provided is correct. Option (B) contains a vague pronoun reference . 2. Counterfactual Reasoning : The option that needs to be looked out for is: Option (A). In option (A), the pronoun ”it” is used, but it has a clear antecedent - the memory card . There is no vague pronoun reference in this option. There is no contradiction. 3. Re-reasoning : 1) The reasoner correctly identifies that option (B) contains a vague pronoun reference. 2) The reasoner considers option (A) and determines that it does not contain a vague pronoun reference. 3) Based on the evaluation of both options, the most likely answer is option (B) as it contains a vague pronoun reference . Answer : B

id_table_10.caption: The response of CoT(SC-CoT).
table: CoT † : Sample 1 : In option (A), the pronoun ”it” refers back to the memory card , which is clear and specific. In option (B), the pronoun ”it” also refers back to the memory card , which is clear and specific. Therefore, neither option contains a vague pronoun reference. Sample 2 : Answer : B In option (A), the pronoun ”it” is used to refer to the memory card . The reference is clear and specific, as it is clear that ”it” refers to the memory card. In option (B), the pronoun ”it” is also used to refer to the memory card. However, the reference is less clear and specific, as there is no clear antecedent for ”it” in the sentence. It is unclear what ”it” is referring to . Therefore, option (B) contains a vague pronoun reference. Answer : Neither
